Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Common-Iliac-Artery Skirt Technology in Iliac Artery Aneurysms

Trial_Design.evidence: Eligible patients were those with iliac artery aneurysms treated with either CST or IIAE.

Participants.evidence: Eligible patients were those with iliac artery aneurysms treated with either CST or IIAE.

Intervention.evidence: compared to internal iliac artery embolization (IIAE) in treating iliac artery aneurysms.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of a novel common-iliac-artery skirt technology (CST) compared to internal iliac artery embolization (IIAE) in treating iliac artery aneurysms.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the technical success rate, defined as complete exclusion of aneurysms without endoleak.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 72 patients were included, with 39 in the CST group and 26 in the IIAE group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: CST demonstrated a shorter surgery time (97.42 ± 3.891 minutes vs. 141.0 ± 8.010 minutes, p < 0.001) and hospital stay (15.35 ± 0.873 days vs. 19.32 ± 1.067 days, p = 0.009).

Harms.evidence: The CST group had lower in-hospital MAEs (0% vs. 11.5%, p = 0.059) and 1-year follow-up MAEs (6.7% vs. 28.6%, p = 0.052).

Funding.evidence: Supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Natural Science Foundation of Hunan Province.
